Catalyst deactivation caused by SO2 poisoning generally hinders commercial viability of CO oxidation catalysts in the field of industrial flue gas purification. XPS results, CO-DRIFTS spectra and DFT calculations suggested that Pt was highly-dispersed and remained the oxidative states on SnO2 support, resulting in that the rate-determining step of CO oxidation is to clean up the adsorbed CO and PtS2 species is readily formed in a SO2-contained hydrothermal environment. It predominantly maintained metallic Pt0 in the Pt/WO3 catalyst, thereby led to cleaning up the activated oxygen atoms as the rate-determining step. It is very difficult to remove the sulfur species in SO2-poisoned catalysts within 600 °C and the mechanisms of CO oxidation are not affected by SO2 poisoning for Pt/SnO2 and Pt/WO3 catalysts. These findings provide some significant insights to understand the mechanisms of CO oxidation and SO2-tolerance. Graphical Abstract Keywords Platinum catalyst In-situ characterization CO oxidation SO2-tolerance Data availability The authors do not have permission to share data. 1 Introduction Toxic carbon monoxide (CO) contaminant in atmospheric environment has been recognized as the unnoticed “21st-century poison" and the “silent assassin", posing a significant threat to human health [1,2]. The well-known CO emission issues predominantly relate to automotive industry, iron and steel industry [3,4]. Unlike automotive exhaust, the coexistence of SO2 and water vapor in industrial flue gas containing CO contaminant poses a great threat to the durability of catalysts [4]. For instance, it generally contains ∼ 1 % CO, 20–200 ppm SO2 and 10–20 % H2O in the sintering flue gas emitted from iron and steel industry [5]. However, we believe that the CO oxidation catalysts will be widely applied in the selective catalytic reduction (SCR) system of the sintering flue gas, in the perspective of energy conservation and CO2 reduction. Thus, it must be very important for environmental applications to develop a robust CO oxidation catalyst with the superior SO2-tolerance. Pt-catalyzed CO oxidation mechanisms started to be investigated at least the 1920s, and two typical reaction mechanisms were proposed: the Langmuir-Hinshelwood (LH) and Mars-van Krevelen (MvK) mechanisms [3,6]. Moreover, Pt exhibits the distinguished dissociative adsorption ability of SO2 and H2S molecules to generate the adsorbed S2– species, which is readily regenerated by oxidizing the covering S2– species towards SO4 2– species migrated to the supports such as Al2O3 and CeO2 when the temperature exceeds 170 ℃ [7,8]. By contrast, the formation of PdSO4 phase in an atmosphere with both SO2 and excess oxygen makes it difficult to regenerate thereby results in deactivation of Pd-supported catalysts, and the rate of formation of PdSO4 will be further raised if there is additional H2O in the actual application environments [9]. The deactivation mode caused by the sulfation of active metals has been also found in many supported catalysts, such as Ru [7], Ag [10] and Cu [11] catalysts. The previous reports suggest that Pt is a superior candidate for the active components of sulfur-resistant CO oxidation catalysts. Unlike the common supported catalysts, applications of catalysts in industrial waste gas purification generally require the selection of supports that can withstand SO2-poisoning. Al2O3 has a high surface area and superior thermal stability, but it is prone to be sulfated to deactivate [12]. CeO2 also readily forms sulfates and sulfites due to its unique outer-shell electrons structure, thereby serving as a sacrificial agent to protect Pt sites [13]. Both TiO2 [14] and SiO2 [15] have been commonly employed as supports for catalysts to resist SO2-poisoning. Moreover, the inherent acidity of WO3 support can effectively mitigate SO2-poisoning, and its high electronegativity can enhance the interactions with Pt active species, facilitating the formation of metallic Pt0 sites that are favorable for CO oxidation [16,17]. Xu et al. [18] reported that the combination of SnO2 with Pt increases active sites associated with oxygen vacancies and forms a Schottky barrier at the metal-oxide interface to enable the rapid adsorption of SO2 into SnO2 to form multivalent sulfides, which enhances detection sensitivity and makes it a commonly used functional material for resistive sensors. In spite of extensive researches focuses on the CO oxidation performance and SO2- tolerance, it remains still unclear for the influence of supports on the microstructures of active Pt phase and the underlying mechanisms of SO2-tolerance. Thus, this work aims to enhance the activity of CO oxidation exposing to mixture gas of O2, SO2 and H2O by selecting CeO2, SnO2, Al2O3, WO3 as the supports of supported Pt catalysts, and further reveal the intrinsic mechanisms. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Supported Pt catalysts were prepared by wet impregnation method. About 20 g of WO3 powder (purchased from Shandong Xiya Chemical Industry Co., Ltd, 99 %) was dispersed in 100 mL deionized water uniformly, followed by addition of 0.58 g Pt(NO3)2 aqueous solution containing 17.63 wt% Pt, and then continuously stirred at 30 ℃ for 2 h. The obtained mixture was dried at 80 °C for 12 h and calcined at 600 °C for 4 h in static air with a heating rate of 10 °C/min to achieve the fresh Pt/WO3-F catalyst. The fresh Pt/SnO2-F, Pt/Al2O3-F, Pt/CeO2-F catalysts were also prepared by the same procedure using SnO2 (Yunnan Tin Company Limited, 98.5 %), Al2O3 (Qinghe County Xingrongyuan metal material Co., Ltd, 99.9 %) and CeO2 (Aladdin Company, 99 %) oxide powders. 60 mg L-Ascorbic acid was dispersed in 20 mL deionized water uniformly, then heated to 80 ℃ and continuously stirred for 30 min, followed by adding 0.58 g Pt(NO3)2 aqueous solution containing 17.63 wt% Pt and 20 g CeO2 powder. The obtained mixture was dried at 80 °C for 12 h and calcined at 600 °C for 4 h in static air with a heating rate of 10 °C/min to achieve the fresh Ptnp/CeO2 catalyst. The reduced catalysts, respectively labeled as Pt/WO3-R, Pt/SnO2-R, Pt/Al2O3-R and Pt/CeO2-R, were achieved by H2 treatment at 350 ℃ in 10 % H2/N2 stream with a total flow rate of 2 L/min for 1 h. The SO2-poisoned Pt/WO3-S, Pt/SnO2-S, Pt/Al2O3-S and Pt/CeO2-S catalysts were obtained by SO2 poisoning experiment at 300 ℃ in stream containing 500 ppm SO2, 10 % O2 and 10 % H2O for 10 h. 2.2 Structure characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the samples were collected on a Rigaku TTRⅢ powder diffractometer with a Cu Kα radiation source operating at 40 kV and 200 mA. High-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) images were observed on a FEI Tecnai F30 TEM instrument operating at 300 kV, and the lattice distances of Pt (111), CeO2 (111), CeO2 (200) and CeO2 (220) crystal planes were determined by using GMS3 software. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were conducted on a K-Alpha + analyzer (Thermo Fisher Scientific) equipped with an Al Kα radiation source. Raman measurements were performed at room temperature using a Renishaw in Via spectrometer with 532 nm excitation light provided by an Ar+ laser as the emission source. Temperature-programmed reduction by H2 (H2-TPR), temperature-programmed desorption of NH3 (NH3-TPD) and CO-pulse experiments were conducted on a ChemBET 3000 chemical adsorption analyzer. As for H2-TPR experiment, 100 mg of the sample was pretreated at 350 °C in Ar stream for 30 min, and then cooled to room temperature and purged with 10 % H2/Ar mixture of 75 mL/min for 50 min, and then heated sample from room temperature to 600 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min. In the case of NH3-TPD experiment, the sample were pretreated at 550 ℃ in 14 % O2/N2 mixture with a total flow rate of 75 mL/min for 30 min and purged using He gas for 20 min. After cooling to 50 ℃, pure NH3 (99.9 %) gas was injected for 50 min, and then switched to He to purge for 60 minutes. The temperature was raised to 400 °C in He stream (75 mL/min) a heating rate of 10 °C/min. Prior to the CO-pulse experiments, the sample was reduced at 450 °C in a 10 % H2/Ar mixture with a total flow rate of 75 mL/min for 60 min. Then, the gas stream was switched to He for 20 min to purge the remaining gas. After being cooled to 50 ℃, pure CO gas (99.9 %) was periodically injected into the reduced sample with a precise analytical syringe. The CO adsorption capacity was calculated by using CO-pulse data to determine Pt dispersion, according to the actual Pt loadings measured by inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES). 2.3 In-situ characterization In-situ diffuse reflectance Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (DRIFTS) spectra were collected on a Thermo iSO50 spectrometer with a MCT detector and a stainless-steel in-situ cell (ZnSe windows). As for fresh and reduced samples, the in-situ cell was flushed with N2 (200 mL/min) and pretreated at 550 °C for 30 minutes before each test. After cooling to 25 ℃, the background spectrum was collected at 25 °C and then switched to 2 % CO/N2 mixture gas with a total flow rate of 200 mL/min. The in-situ DRIFTS spectra were collected each 2 min for CO adsorption and desorption. To investigate the CO oxidation mechanism, the in-situ DRIFTS spectra were collected each 50 °C from 50 °C to 550 °C in reaction mixture gas stream containing 2 % CO and 10 % O2 with a total flow rate of 200 mL/min. In case of SO2-poisoned catalysts, the in-situ cell was flushed with 200 mL/min N2 gas and pretreated at 600 °C for 30 min before each test, then collected the background spectra each 50 °C from 50 °C to 600 °C and in-situ DRIFTS spectra using the same procedure for fresh samples to investigate the CO adsorption behavior over the SO2-poisoned catalysts. A S-free sample was placed in an in-situ cell and pretreated at 600 °C for 30 min with 200 mL/min N2 gas, and then cooled to 50 °C. The background spectra each 50 °C from 50 °C to 600 °C in 200 mL/min N2 stream. The sample was taken out and the in-situ cell was filled with the corresponding SO2-poisoned sample to investigate the SO2 desorption behavior, collecting the in-situ DRIFTS spectra each 50 °C from 50 °C to 600 °C in 200 mL/min N2 stream. In-situ Raman spectra were collected on a Thermo DXRTM3xi spectrometer using 3.2 mW laser power. In the experiments, about 50 mg of SO2-poisoned catalyst sample was placed in an in-situ cell and 200 mL/min N2 flow was introduced to collect the in-situ DRIFTS spectra 50 °C from 50 °C to 600 °C. 2.4 Computational method The calculations were performed by means of density functional theory (DFT) methods using the Vienna Ab-initio Simulation Package (VASP) [19–21]. The electron-ion interactions were described by using projector augmented wave (PAW) method [22,23]. The exchange and correlation energies were determined with the Perdew, Burke, and Ernzerhof (PBE) functional was used [24,25]. To accurately describe the dispersion interaction, we use DFT-D3 method with Becke-Jonson damping for dispersion correction. The cutoff energy of plane-wave basis was 400 eV. The geometry optimization was performed until the Hellmann-Feynman force on each atom is smaller than 0.05 eV/Å. The energy criterion was set to 10−4 eV in the iterative solution of the Kohn-Sham equation. The Brillouin-zone sampling was conducted using Monkhorst-Pack grids of special points with the separation of 0.07 Å−1, and a Gaussian smearing of 0.05 eV was applied to speed up electronic convergence. The 3-layer 2 × 2 supercell of WO3(001) (14.768 Å × 15.024 Å) and 3-layer 4 × 3 supercell of SnO2(110) (12.750 × 14.404 Å) were used to build the calculation models of Pt/WO3 and Pt/SnO2, respectively. The bottom two layers were fixed while other atoms were fully relaxed. Metallic Pt0 clusters and atomically-dispersed Ptδ+ ions were respectively selected to build the calculation models of Pt/WO3 and Pt/SnO2 according to the XPS and CO-DRIFTS results. The transition states were determined using the climbing image nudged elastic band (CI-NEB) method with the energy convergence tolerance of 0.05 eV/Å. A vacuum height of 15 Å along the vertical direction was selected to avoid the unwanted interaction between the slab and its period images. The activation energy (E a) of a chemical reaction was defined as the energy difference between the transition state and initial state, while the reaction energy (ΔE) was defined as the energy difference between the final and initial states. 2.5 Catalytic performance test The catalysts granules with 40–60 mesh were prepared by tableting, crushing and sieving to evaluate the activity of CO oxidation using a fixed bed with a quartz microreactor (inner diameter of 5 mm). After placing ∼ 500 mg of catalysts granules in quartz microreactor, 1 L/min of reaction mixture gas containing 2 %CO and 10 % O2/N2 was introduced to maintain a gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 120,000 mL∙h−1∙g−1. Temperature dependence of reaction was performed in light-off mode by two cycles, and the results of second cycling tests were employed to present the light-off curves. The concentration of CO was analyzed online using a FT-IR analyzer and the CO conversion was calculated by the Eq. (1). (1) CO conversion = [ CO in ] − [ CO out ] [ CO in ] × 100 % Where [COin] and [COout] present the inlet and outlet CO concentrations, respectively. The reaction rate (r) of CO oxidation at certain temperature and the apparent activation energy (E a) calculated by the Eqs. (2) and (3) [26]. (2) r = 2 % × CO conversion ( % ) × Flowrate ( L / min ) 22.4 ( L / mol ) × m ( g ) × SSA BET ( m 2 / g ) × 60 mol / ( m 2 · s ) (3) ln r = − E a RT + aln [ CO in ] + bln [ O 2 ] 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Chemical composition and textural properties The textural and structure parameters of the fresh catalysts were summarized in Table S1, showing that the specific surface area was 10.6, 4.4, 130.5 and 137.8 m2/g while Pt dispersion was 17.8 %, 21.3 %, 35.6 % and 37.8 % for the Pt/WO3-F, Pt/SnO2-F, Pt/Al2O3-F, Pt/CeO2-F catalysts, respectively. These results suggest that the Pt dispersion strongly depends on the nature of supports. The actual Pt loadings in the catalysts were close to the target contents (∼ 0.5 wt%) according to ICP-OES results. In XRD patterns of fresh and H2-reduced catalysts (Fig. S1), no observation of Pt diffraction peak (2θ = 39.782°, PDF #04-001-0112) indicate that Pt remains highly dispersed over the supports, compared to that of Ptnp/CeO2 catalyst. 3.2 Microstructure of Pt active sites XPS technique was employed to analyze the valence states of active Pt species and metal elements in supports. In consideration of overlaps of the Pt 4f and Al 2p spectral regions, the signals of Pt 4d orbitals was employed to identify the chemical states of active Pt species in Pt/Al2O3 catalysts [27], whereas the Pt 4f spectral region was scanned for Al-free supported Pt catalysts ( Fig. 1a–b). CeO2 is reducible due to the co-existence of Ce3+ and Ce4+ species, which effectively suppresses the generation of metallic Pt0. The active Pt phase was consisted of 92 % Pt2+ and 8 % Pt4+ species in the Pt/CeO2-F catalyst. Containing 26 % Ce3+ species can provide the coordination unsaturated electrophilic points, allowing the transfer of electrons from Pt towards CeO2 to form the stabilized platinum oxides [28]. The experimental Pt 4f region curve of Pt/WO3-F catalyst was well fitted with four Gaussian-Lorentzian peaks centered at 70.0 eV, 71.3 eV, 74.3 eV and 74.8 eV as shown in Fig. 1a and Table S2. The peaks at 71.3 eV and 74.8 eV can be assigned to core-level of Pt1+ 4f 7/2 and Pt1+ 4f 5/2, showing a relative percentage of 6 %. Interestingly, Pt was predominantly metallic in the Pt/WO3-F catalyst although WO3 support was consisted of 91 % W6+ and 9 % W5+ species, which agrees well with the literature [29]. The result suggests that WO3-x is also reducible and can act as the scavenger of oxygen atoms surrounding Pt atoms. As for the inert Al2O3 support, it was observed that the supported Pt is the co-existence of metallic Pt0 and oxidized Pt δ+. By contrast, SnO2 is also inert but the supported Pt maintains the oxidation states with 58 % Pt2+ and 42 % Pt4+ species, consistent with the literature [30]. Above mentioned results illustrate that the chemical states of active Pt components are strongly dependent the properties of supports in supported Pt catalysts. To further characterize the nature of active Pt sites, in-situ DRIFTS spectra were collected during adsorption and desorption on Pt atoms at 25 °C. The results were displayed in Fig. 1c–d and Fig. S3–S5, and the attributions of CO adsorption were summarized in Table S3–S4. As for Pt/WO3-F sample, it was observed two broad peaks centered at 2063 and 1872 cm–1, which can be respectively attributed to the C-O vibrations of linear and bridged carbonyl species adsorbed on the metallic Pt0 atoms as well as Pt+ sites [31]. However, the band at ∼ 2180 cm–1 assigned to the surface W6+–CO species was difficult to be detected [32], suggesting the lack of weak Lewis acid sites in Pt/WO3-F due to its extremely low specific surface area (Table S1). It's interesting that H2 treatment at 350 ℃ resulted in disappearing the C-O vibrations of CO terminally adsorbed on Pt. These observations can be attributed to the weaken Pt-CO bonding caused by the increased electron density of Pt after H2 treatment [32]. Three bands at 2100, 2089 and 2071 cm–1, close related to the linearly adsorbed CO on Pt4+, Pt2+ and Pt0 sites, were observed in CO-DRIFTS spectra of Pt/Al2O3-F. After H2 treatment, the intensity of monocarbonyl significantly increased and it appeared an additional shoulder at 1841 cm–1 assigned to bridged carbonyl species (Fig. S4c). In addition, the band assigned Pt0–CO shifted to a lower wavenumber by 6 cm–1. According to XPS results (Fig. 1a and Fig. S5), the relative Pt0 increment of 20 % can promote the back-donation of electrons in metallic Pt0 towards the CO 2π* antibonding orbitals [33], explaining the “red shift” observation. Both Pt/SnO2-F and Pt/SnO2-R, CO-DRIFTS spectra showed three bands at 2117, 2096 and 2071 cm–1 although the intensity was slightly decreased after H2 treatment. Thus, it can be concluded that CO was adsorbed on PtO in Pt/SnO2 samples (Table S4) and the decreased intensity was close related to the reduction of PtO into metallic Pt0 (Fig. 1a and Fig. S5). Moreover, no observation of the band belonging to bridged carbonyls suggests that Pt might be atomically dispersed. From CO-DRIFTS spectra of Pt/CeO2-F, it can be seen four peaks centered at 2102, 2089, 2068 and 1844 cm–1, respectively responding to the C-O vibrations of linearly adsorbed CO on PtO x nanoparticle surfaces, terraces and step sites and bridged carbonyl bonded to the neighbor Pt atoms [34]. These observations indicate that PtO x was dispersed on the surfaces of CeO2 in the form of nanoparticles, and size of PtO x nanoparticle was about 8 nm according to the HRTEM results (Fig. S6). In the case of Pt/CeO2-R, the DRIFTS spectra showed a significant increase in intensity of monocarbonyl species adsorbed on PtO x clusters or nanoparticles, and disappeared the C-O vibrations of bridged carbonyls but appeared a band at 2156 cm–1 corresponded to the carbonyl bonded to Ceδ+ cations, suggesting the enhancement of CO adsorption and spillover induced by H2 treatment. 3.3 Surface oxygen species and acidity properties As shown in Fig. 2a, the O 1s spectrum of Pt/WO3 sample was fitted by three Gaussian peaks centered at 530.5, 531.5 and 533.0 eV, which should be respectively assigned to the lattice oxygen (Olat) bonded to hexavalent tungsten, adsorbed oxygen-containing species (Oads) on metallic Pt0 and W5+ sites [35], according to the XPS results. The corresponding H2-TPR profile (Fig. 2b) showed three hydrogen consumption peaks at 242, 345 and 533 ℃. The first two peaks can be ascribed to the reduction of adsorbed oxygen-containing species on metallic Pt0 and W5+ sites, while the peak at 533 ℃ was probably associated with the hydrogen consumption caused by the H2-spillover effect to generate W4O11 species followed the reactions (I) and (II) [36]. (I) H2–Pt0 → Pt0 + 2H (II) 2H∙ + 4WO3 → W4O11 + H2O By contrast, the O 1s spectra of the other three samples showed two Gaussian peaks, responding to the Olat and Oads species on supports and platinum, including Pt oxides. The O 1s binding energy of Olat species in Pt/CeO2 sample was 529.0 eV, lowered approximately 1.6 eV compared to that of Pt/Al2O3 and Pt/WO3. These results is well consistent with the previous report [37]. No hydrogen consumption peak was observed in H2-TPR profile of Pt/Al2O3. We believe that this is the result of signal counteraction between release of adsorbed hydrogen at low-temperature and hydrogen consumption by PtO x species in region of 100–200 ℃. As for Pt/SnO2, the weak peaks centered at 182 and 349 ℃ were respectively due to the reduction of PtO x and oxygen species in the vicinity of Pt, whereas the strong TCD signals above 470 ℃ were close related to the reduction of Sn4+ species into Sn2+ [38,39]. H2-TPR profile of Pt/CeO2 appeared three peaks at 124, 160 and 198 ℃, which responds to the reduction of surface Pt–O species and activated oxygen in the vicinity of Pt [40,41]. This superior reducibility can provide a reasonable explanation why the binding energy of Olat species in Pt/CeO2 was much lower than other samples. In Fig. 2c, NH3-TPD profiles of Pt/Al2O3 and Pt/CeO2 showed an asymmetric curvilinear shape, suggesting that three are at least two NH3 desorption peaks. The peak centered at 159 ℃ or 166 ℃ can be assigned to the weak acid sites, and the TCD signals detected at higher temperature were attributed to the strong acid sites [42]. As for Pt/SnO2 and Pt/WO3, however no signal was detected, which indicates the lack of exposed acid sites due to the very poor specific surface area (Table S1). These results were also confirmed by the in-situ DRIFTS spectra of NH3 adsorption (Fig. S7). The Raman spectra in Fig. 2d exhibited the O-W-O (273 and 328 cm–1) bending and W-O (719 and 809 cm–1) stretching modes in Pt/WO3, and the F2g mode associated with the stretching of Ce-O symmetrical vibrational in Pt/CeO2 [43,44]. 3.4 Activity and mechanisms for catalytic CO oxidation As shown in Fig. 3a–b, the Pt/CeO2-F catalyst showed a light-off temperature (T 50) of 65 ℃ for CO oxidation and an E a value of 37.4 kJ/mol, which shows a better catalytic activity than that of single-atom Pt/CeO2 catalyst reported by Wang and his co-workers [41]. The H2 treatment resulted in a T 50 decline of 52 % to reach 31 ℃ (Fig. S8) due to the significant reduction of oxygenated PtO x species towards metallic Pt0 (Fig. 1a and Fig. S5), indicating that CO is more readily oxidized on the Pt sites with lower valent. The Pt/Al2O3 and Pt/WO3 also followed a same rule for the valent-dependent activity of CO oxidation. However, the T 50 for CO conversion increased to 174 ℃ when Pt/SnO2 was reduced in H2 stream at 350 ℃ (Fig. S8b). The results suggest that isolated ionic Pt sites on the SnO2 can be recognized as the vital active centers for CO oxidation in combination with CO-DRIFTS results. Fig. S5 and Fig. S8b shows that the formation of metallic Pt0 resulted in the loss of catalytic activity for CO oxidation over the Pt/SnO2 catalyst, but promoted CO oxidation over the Pt/CeO2, Pt/Al2O3 and Pt/WO3 catalysts. In addition, the catalytic activity and apparent activation energy followed the order of Pt/CeO2 > Pt/SnO2 > Pt/Al2O3 > Pt/WO3 (Fig. 3a–b, Fig. S8a and Table S5). Thus, we concluded that CO oxidation over the supported Pt catalysts strongly depend on the support properties as well as Pt states. In-situ DRIFTS technique was employed to explore the support-dependent mechanisms of CO oxidation, and the results were shown in Fig. 3c–d, Fig. S9 and S10. The oxy-carbon intermediates (summarized in Table S6 and S7) were clearly detected in the region of 1800–1000 cm–1 during CO oxidation over the Pt/CeO2 and Pt/Al2O3 catalysts. CO oxidation reaction follows the carbonate pathway over the Pt/CeO2-F and Pt/CeO2-R catalysts, while the formation of metallic Pt0 sites promotes CO adsorption and carbonate generation at low-temperature (Fig. 3c and Fig. S10a). The H2 treatment blocked the formate (1474 and 1337 cm–1) pathway over the Pt/Al2O3 catalyst to follow the bicarbonate pathway. In the case of Pt/SnO2-F and Pt/WO3-F catalysts, the weak vibrations of carbonates can be observed when the reaction temperature exceeds 200 ℃. However, the oxy-carbon intermediates were hardly detected during CO oxidation over the Pt/SnO2-R and Pt/WO3-R catalysts. The DFT calculation was performed to further understand the intrinsic mechanisms for CO oxidation over the Pt/SnO2 and Pt/WO3 catalysts, and the calculated energy profiles were shown in Fig. 4. As for the Pt/WO3 catalyst, the co-adsorption energy of CO and O2 forming a relatively stable OC-O2* intermediate (Fig. 4, intermediate III) is higher than the individual adsorption energy of CO by 0.29 eV. However, the formation energy of OC-O2* intermediate is slightly lower than the energy of CO adsorbed on the surface of Pt/SnO2 catalyst by 0.24 eV, with an exothermic step. The activation barriers (E a1 ) to release first CO2 from the OC-O2* intermediate (Fig. 4, intermediate V) were respectively 0.28 eV and 0.07 eV for Pt/SnO2 and Pt/WO3 catalysts, while the activation barriers (E a2 ) to remove the activated oxygen atoms (O*) by another CO for producing the second CO2 molecule were 0.44 eV and 0.09 eV. These results indicate that the cleaning up the adsorbed CO and activated oxygen atoms can be respectively recognized as the rate-determining step for CO oxidation over the Pt/SnO2 and Pt/WO3 catalysts, and reasonably explain why Pt/SnO2 catalyst exhibits much better low-temperature activity than that of Pt/WO3 catalyst. 3.5 Mechanisms of SO2-tolerance Light-off curves of CO conversion ( Fig. 5a) showed that the catalytic activity decreased as follows: Pt/SnO2-S > Pt/CeO2-S > Pt/Al2O3-S > Pt/WO3-S, which is attributed to the significant activity loss of Pt/CeO2 catalyst caused by SO2-poisoning showing a T 50 increment rate of 177 % (Fig. 5b). Pt/SnO2 catalyst exhibited the best activity for CO oxidation after SO2 poisoning experiment although the T 50 increment rate reached 19 %, indicating that Pt/SnO2 catalyst has the most superior SO2-tolerance. By contrast, the T 50 increment rates were 13 % and 1.7 % for Pt/Al2O3 and Pt/WO3, respectively. These results suggest that Pt/WO3 catalyst has the highest ability to resist SO2 poisoning. To understand the mechanisms of SO2-tolerance, the surface analysis of SO2-poisoned catalysts was carried out using XPS technique. Fig. 5c displayed the Pt 4f XPS spectra of SO2-poisoned catalysts. The Pt 4f XPS spectrum of Pt/WO3-S proved the coexistence of Pt0 and Pt2+ species, illustrating the metallic Pt0 can be slightly oxidized to Pt in divalent state under the SO2-contained hydrothermal condition at 300 ℃. A similar phenomenon was observed in Pt/Al2O3, showing that ∼ 10 % of Pt0 was oxidized to Ptδ+ species after SO2 poisoning. In Pt/SnO2-S catalyst, however active Pt species were consisted of 72 % Pt2+ and 28 % Pt4+, which indicates the transformation of ∼ 33 % Pt4+ into Pt2+ species caused by SO2 poisoning. Moreover, loss of the relative Pt4+ percentage might also be related to the formation of PtS2 species as shown in Fig. 5d. Hydrothermal aging in oxidizing environment contained SO2 resulted in the partial decomposition of Ptδ+ species into the lower valence states. The S 2p XPS spectra of SO2-poisoned catalysts were showed in Fig. 5c and the detailed binding energies (BE) of S species were summarized in Table S8. All catalysts exhibited two main XPS peaks centered at 168.7–169.3 eV and 169.8–170.4 eV that are attributed to the 2p 3/2 and 2p 1/2 of S elements in sulfites and sulfates [4,8,45], providing the evidence of residual SO x 2– presence. In Pt/SnO2 catalyst, another species were characterized by the BE(S 2p 3/2) = 164.1 eV and BE(S 2p 3/2) = 159.4 eV, which can be assigned to the PtS2 and SnS species, respectively [46,47]. The formation of PtS2 species significantly inhibited the CO adsorption on Pt atoms (Fig. S9a and Fig. S11). The double peaks at 161.8 eV and 163.0 eV are close related to the S 2p 3/2 and 2p 1/2 of WS3 species [48]. These results indicate that SO2 molecules were dissociated by Pt atoms into S2– species, which reacted with PtO2 to form PtS2 and migrated to the supports. The evolution behaviors were investigated by collecting the in-situ DRIFT and Raman spectra of SO2-poisoned catalysts in N2 stream to further understand the mechanisms of SO2-tolerance. As shown in Fig. S12a, the presence of sulfates (SO4 2–) in Pt/CeO2-S catalyst was further confirmed by the observations of SO stretching vibrations at 1392–1330 cm–1 and 1125–986 cm–1 [49,50]. The band at 1175 cm–1 can be assigned to the characteristic vibration of bisulfates (HSO4 –) [50]. As can be seen in Fig. S13a, the stretching vibrations of Ceδ+–CO (2156 cm–1) and Pt–CO (2102, 2089 and 2068 cm–1) modes disappeared after SO2 poisoning, which illustrates that CeO2 was sulfated and Pt was passivated because Pt favors to promote the ceria sulfation [51]. Fig. S12b indicated that the Pt/SnO2-S catalyst also contained sulfates (1387–1355 cm–1, 1103–985 cm–1) and bisulfates (1169 cm–1), but their densities were much lower than that of Pt/CeO2-S catalyst. Fig. S13b showed that exposing in SO2-contained hydrothermal atmosphere weakened CO adsorbed on Pt sites, which is ascribed to the formation of PtS2 phase according to the XPS results. Moreover, increasing temperature to 600 ℃ led to the increase in intensity of peaks assigned to SO4 2– and HSO4 – species, illustrating that it is very difficult to remove these sulfates and bisulfates within 600 ℃ in N2 atmosphere. In-situ Raman spectra of Pt/SnO2-S catalyst ( Fig. 6a) presented two weak peaks centered at 313 and 333 cm–1 corresponding to the in-plane (Eg) and out-of-plane (Ag) vibrations of PtS2 species, respectively, which agrees well with XPS results [52]. The strong peak at 615 cm–1 can be attributed to the A1g expansion vibration mode of SnO bonds in SnO2-SnS pairs [53], due to no observation of this characteristic Raman peak in Pt/SnO2-F catalyst. The peak intensity was declined with a “red shift”, reaching 601 cm–1, when the temperature was gradually raised to 600 ℃. As above mentioned, it can be concluded that S2– species were converted into SO4 2– and HSO4 – species. In the case of Pt/Al2O3-S catalyst, the peaks assigned to sulfite (SO3 2–) species (1120–960 cm–1) and adsorbed SO2 (1303 cm–1 and 1272 cm–1) declined and the characteristic vibration of SO4 2– (1398–1367 cm–1) increased with the increments in 300 ℃ (Fig. S12c) [54], suggesting that SO3 2– species and adsorbed SO2 were transformed into sulfates at higher temperature. The characteristic vibrations of SO4 2– (∼ 1399 cm–1) and SO3 2– species on the surface of Pt/WO3-S catalyst increased when the temperature exceeded 300 ℃ (Fig. S12d). Unlike Pt/CeO2-S and Pt/SnO2-S catalysts, the clean Pt surfaces maintained in Pt/Al2O3-S and Pt/WO3-S catalysts can be evidenced with CO adsorption behaviors as displayed in Fig. 1c and Fig. S13c–d. In in-situ Raman spectra of Pt/WO3-S catalyst (Fig. 6b), the four characteristic Raman peaks observed at 258, 315, 702 and 795 cm–1, respectively correspond to the O-W-O (258 and 315 cm–1) bending and W-O (702 and 795 cm–1) stretching modes, which are lower than that of Pt/WO3-F catalyst. This observation might be related to the presence of WO3-WS3 pairs according to the XPS results, showing the significant differences with Raman spectra of Pt/Al2O3 catalysts (Fig. S14). Thus, we believe that the detection of sulfites and sulfates should result from the transformation of WS3 species, because of the declined intensity and “red shift” of O-W-O bending and W-O stretching modes with increasing temperature. There is no significant difference in the structure evolutions of S-contained species as function of temperature between in N2 stream and in 2 % CO/N2 stream (Fig. S13, Fig. S14 and Table S9), indicating that the regeneration of SO2-poisoned catalysts seems to be still very difficult even in CO-contained reducing atmosphere. Comparing the in-situ DRIFT spectra displayed in Fig. 3c and Fig. S15a, it was found that mono- or poly- dentate carbonates disappeared during CO oxidation over the Pt/CeO2-S catalyst, but it still followed carbonate pathway. By contrast, as shown in Fig. S9b and Fig. S15b, the intermediates on the Pt/Al2O3-S catalyst remained bicarbonates and formates even exposing to SO2, however their intensity decreased clearly that is the reason for loss of low-temperature activity. As for Pt/SnO2 and Pt/WO3 catalysts, there is no significant changes in the intensities and types of surface carbonates (Fig. S9a and Fig. 6c–d), which can explain why Pt/SnO2 and Pt/WO3 catalysts exhibit a better SO2-tolerance compared to Pt/Al2O3 catalyst. 4 Conclusion Understanding the SO2-tolerance mechanisms of catalysts seems to be vital to design a durable catalyst for industrial applications. Thus, this work focused on the applied basic research of supported Pt catalysts, based on the potential demands and significant challenges of CO oxidation catalyst for application in further purifying the sintering flue gas emitted from iron and steel industry. It was found that WO3-x acts as a scavenger of oxygen atoms surrounding Pt atoms, which favors the formation of metallic Pt0 sites. Selecting the SnO2 support helps to achieve the highly-dispersed active sites with oxidative Ptδ+ species. Pt/CeO2 catalyst showed the higher low-temperature activity than other supported Pt catalysts, which is attributed to its superior reducibility. Both support properties and Pt states have significantly affect on catalytic activity for CO oxidation, and how the Pt states affects catalytic activity largely depends on the support properties. Cleaning up the adsorbed CO was found the rate-determining step for CO oxidation over the Pt/SnO2 catalyst, while cleaning up the activated oxygen atoms was recognized as the rate-determining step for Pt/WO3 catalyst. Pt/WO3 and Pt/SnO2 catalysts showed a superior SO2-tolerance, due to the dissociation of SO2 into S2− species to react with PtO2 to form PtS2 and migrate to the supports to form WS3 and SnS, as well as a few negative effect of SO2 poisoning on the mechanisms of CO oxidation. These findings are beneficial for developing the long-term CO oxidation catalysts. CRediT authorship contribution statement Yang Weinan: Validation, Supervision. Tian Dong: Software. coredata.dc:description: Catalyst deactivation caused by SO2 poisoning generally hinders commercial viability of CO oxidation catalysts in the field of industrial flue gas purification. XPS results, CO-DRIFTS spectra and DFT calculations suggested that Pt was highly-dispersed and remained the oxidative states on SnO2 support, resulting in that the rate-determining step of CO oxidation is to clean up the adsorbed CO and PtS2 species is readily formed in a SO2-contained hydrothermal environment. It predominantly maintained metallic Pt0 in the Pt/WO3 catalyst, thereby led to cleaning up the activated oxygen atoms as the rate-determining step. It is very difficult to remove the sulfur species in SO2-poisoned catalysts within 600 °C and the mechanisms of CO oxidation are not affected by SO2 poisoning for Pt/SnO2 and Pt/WO3 catalysts. These findings provide some significant insights to understand the mechanisms of CO oxidation and SO2-tolerance.
